00045 #include <avr32/io.h>
00046 #include "compiler.h"
00047 #include "preprocessor.h"
00048 #include "intc.h"
00049 
00050 
00052 extern const unsigned int ipr_val[AVR32_INTC_NUM_INT_LEVELS];
00053 
00056 #define DECL_INT_LINE_HANDLER_TABLE(GRP, unused) \
00057 static volatile __int_handler _int_line_handler_table_##GRP[Max(AVR32_INTC_NUM_IRQS_PER_GRP##GRP, 1)];
00058 MREPEAT(AVR32_INTC_NUM_INT_GRPS, DECL_INT_LINE_HANDLER_TABLE, ~);
00059 #undef DECL_INT_LINE_HANDLER_TABLE
00060 
00063 static const struct
00064 {
00065   unsigned int num_irqs;
00066   volatile __int_handler *_int_line_handler_table;
00067 } _int_handler_table[AVR32_INTC_NUM_INT_GRPS] =
00068 {
00069 #define INSERT_INT_LINE_HANDLER_TABLE(GRP, unused) \
00070   {AVR32_INTC_NUM_IRQS_PER_GRP##GRP, _int_line_handler_table_##GRP},
00071   MREPEAT(AVR32_INTC_NUM_INT_GRPS, INSERT_INT_LINE_HANDLER_TABLE, ~)
00072 #undef INSERT_INT_LINE_HANDLER_TABLE
00073 };
00074 
00075 
00080 #if __GNUC__
00081 __attribute__((__interrupt__))
00082 #elif __ICCAVR32__
00083 __interrupt
00084 #endif
00085 static void _unhandled_interrupt(void)
00086 {
00087   // Catch unregistered interrupts.
00088   while (TRUE);
00089 }
00090 
00091 
00101 __int_handler _get_interrupt_handler(unsigned int int_lev)
00102 {
00103   // ICR3 is mapped first, ICR0 last.
00104   // Code in exception.S puts int_lev in R12 which is used by AVR32-GCC to pass
00105   // a single argument to a function.
00106   unsigned int int_grp = (&AVR32_INTC.icr3)[INT3 - int_lev];
00107   unsigned int int_req = AVR32_INTC.irr[int_grp];
00108 
00109   // As an interrupt may disappear while it is being fetched by the CPU
00110   // (spurious interrupt caused by a delayed response from an MCU peripheral to
00111   // an interrupt flag clear or interrupt disable instruction), check if there
00112   // are remaining interrupt lines to process.
00113   // If a spurious interrupt occurs, the status register (SR) contains an
00114   // execution mode and interrupt level masks corresponding to a level 0
00115   // interrupt, whatever the interrupt priority level causing the spurious
00116   // event. This behavior has been chosen because a spurious interrupt has not
00117   // to be a priority one and because it may not cause any trouble to other
00118   // interrupts.
00119   // However, these spurious interrupts place the hardware in an unstable state
00120   // and could give problems in other/future versions of the CPU, so the
00121   // software has to be written so that they never occur. The only safe way of
00122   // achieving this is to always clear or disable peripheral interrupts with the
00123   // following sequence:
00124   // 1: Mask the interrupt in the CPU by setting GM (or IxM) in SR.
00125   // 2: Perform the bus access to the peripheral register that clears or
00126   //    disables the interrupt.
00127   // 3: Wait until the interrupt has actually been cleared or disabled by the
00128   //    peripheral. This is usually performed by reading from a register in the
00129   //    same peripheral (it DOES NOT have to be the same register that was
00130   //    accessed in step 2, but it MUST be in the same peripheral), what takes
00131   //    bus system latencies into account, but peripheral internal latencies
00132   //    (generally 0 cycle) also have to be considered.
00133   // 4: Unmask the interrupt in the CPU by clearing GM (or IxM) in SR.
00134   // Note that steps 1 and 4 are useless inside interrupt handlers as the
00135   // corresponding interrupt level is automatically masked by IxM (unless IxM is
00136   // explicitly cleared by the software).
00137   //
00138   // Get the right IRQ handler.
00139   //
00140   // If several interrupt lines are active in the group, the interrupt line with
00141   // the highest number is selected. This is to be coherent with the
00142   // prioritization of interrupt groups performed by the hardware interrupt
00143   // controller.
00144   //
00145   // If no handler has been registered for the pending interrupt,
00146   // _unhandled_interrupt will be selected thanks to the initialization of
00147   // _int_line_handler_table_x by INTC_init_interrupts.
00148   //
00149   // exception.S will provide the interrupt handler with a clean interrupt stack
00150   // frame, with nothing more pushed onto the stack. The interrupt handler must
00151   // manage the `rete' instruction, what can be done thanks to pure assembly,
00152   // inline assembly or the `__attribute__((__interrupt__))' C function
00153   // attribute.
00154   return (int_req) ? _int_handler_table[int_grp]._int_line_handler_table[32 - clz(int_req) - 1] : NULL;
00155 }
00156 
00157 
00158 void INTC_init_interrupts(void)
00159 {
00160   unsigned int int_grp, int_req;
00161 
00162   // For all interrupt groups,
00163   for (int_grp = 0; int_grp < AVR32_INTC_NUM_INT_GRPS; int_grp++)
00164   {
00165     // For all interrupt request lines of each group,
00166     for (int_req = 0; int_req < _int_handler_table[int_grp].num_irqs; int_req++)
00167     {
00168       // Assign _unhandled_interrupt as default interrupt handler.
00169       _int_handler_table[int_grp]._int_line_handler_table[int_req] = &_unhandled_interrupt;
00170     }
00171 
00172     // Set the interrupt group priority register to its default value.
00173     // By default, all interrupt groups are linked to the interrupt priority
00174     // level 0 and to the interrupt vector _int0.
00175     AVR32_INTC.ipr[int_grp] = ipr_val[INT0];
00176   }
00177 }
00178 
00179 
00180 void INTC_register_interrupt(__int_handler handler, unsigned int irq, unsigned int int_lev)
00181 {
00182   // Determine the group of the IRQ.
00183   unsigned int int_grp = irq / AVR32_INTC_MAX_NUM_IRQS_PER_GRP;
00184 
00185   // Store in _int_line_handler_table_x the pointer to the interrupt handler, so
00186   // that _get_interrupt_handler can retrieve it when the interrupt is vectored.
00187   _int_handler_table[int_grp]._int_line_handler_table[irq % AVR32_INTC_MAX_NUM_IRQS_PER_GRP] = handler;
00188 
00189   // Program the corresponding IPRX register to set the interrupt priority level
00190   // and the interrupt vector offset that will be fetched by the core interrupt
00191   // system.
00192   // NOTE: The _intx functions are intermediate assembly functions between the
00193   // core interrupt system and the user interrupt handler.
00194   AVR32_INTC.ipr[int_grp] = ipr_val[int_lev & (AVR32_INTC_IPR0_INTLEV_MASK >> AVR32_INTC_IPR0_INTLEV_OFFSET)];
00195 }
